content.data: We begin with the following simple program:

In Java, unlike Python (for example) if you want to store a piece of information you have to tell the environment what **type **of information you want to store. 


```
int age;
```


This line of code stores whole numbers (integers or as we say in Java: **int**). We attach a label to this data: **age**. We can then hold values in it:


```
age = 18;
```


We can, of course, do both steps in one line of code:


```
int age = 18;
```

content.data:
_Logical Operators_

Here is a list of basic logical operators

! - Not - Returns true if the operand to the
right evaluates to false. Returns false if the operand to the right is true.


& - And - Returns true if both of the operands
evaluate to true. Both operands are
evaluated before the And operator is applied.


| - or - Returns true if at least one of the
operands evaluates to true. Both operands
are evaluated before the Or operator is applied.


&& - Conditional And - Same as &, but if the operand on the left returns false, it returns false without evaluating the operand on the
right.


^ - Xor - Returns true if one — and only
one — of the operands evaluates to true. Returns false if both operands evaluate to true or if
both operands evaluate to false.


|| - Same as |, but if the operand on the left returns true, it returns true without evaluating the operand on the
right.

_How to exit a while loop_

Let’s build a mechanism to allow us to stop and start the loop, from within a loop:

We introduce a control variable:


```
boolean controlSwitch = true;
```


This is used inside the loop checking mechanism:


```
while(controlSwitch){ ; }
```


So far the same as our infinite loop. However, we introduce an input and an internal mechanism to check the input value and then toggle the boolean value:
In this version if someone enters a **-1 **the controlSwitch will reverse and the code will stop repeating. Test it.

_Arrays Introdution_

**Introduction**

Before starting this material please make sure you are confident with the following concepts:



*   data types
*   variables

In this session we introduce the **array**. This is a core data structure that allows you to store a** number** of items of the **same data type**. The array will play an important role throughout the semester. 

**Method 1**

You can initialise an array by giving it values:

**Method 2**

For an array you have to do 2 things when you create an array:



1. Tell it what type of data you are storing. In this case an integer. The [] bracket tells the system you are declaring an array.

    ```
int[] intArr;
```


2. Tell it how the number of items of this data type you want.

    ```
int[] intArr = new int[5];
```



Then you would add the items using the index value, for example:


```
intArr[3] = 4;
```
